questions.question_text:
A FortiGate device has the following LDAP configuration:
config user ldap
edit "WindowsLDAP"
set server "10.0.1.10"
set cnid "cn"
set dn "cn=Users, dc=trainingAD, dc=training, dc=lab"
set type regular
set username "dc=trainingAD, dc=training, dc=lab"
set password xxxxxxx
next
end
The administrator executed the 'dsquery' command in the Windows LDAP server 10.0.1.10, and got the following output:
>dsquery user -samid administrator
"CN=Administrator, CN=Users, DC=trainingAD, DC=training, DC=lab"
Based on the output, what FortiGate LDAP setting is configured incorrectly?

Examine the IPsec configuration shown in the exhibit; then answer the question below.
//IMG//

An administrator wants to monitor the VPN by enabling the IKE real time debug using these commands: diagnose vpn ike log-filter src-addr4 10.0.10.1 diagnose debug application ike -1 diagnose debug enable
The VPN is currently up, there is no traffic crossing the tunnel and DPD packets are being interchanged between both IPsec gateways. However, the IKE real time debug does NOT show any output. Why isn't there any output?

discussion.content: The questions on this are almost completely absent from the current NSE7 test being given. Fortinet's own training doesn't cover the material. Heavy focus on ADVPN/Community VPN, OSPF/BGP and central management.
Tested in my lab, this is A

A correct
dst-addr4 usualy is used because if you have one phase1-int with many phase2, you will get a lot of spam in the output, but it is good filter for p2p connection. In this case "Remote" is just name, it is a "local" device and it has correct ip for the src filter.

I also say it is probably B) according to 6.4 Study Guide p435. 
dst-addr4 is used in combination with the remote gateway to filter. If we use the src-addr4 option, we should use the local value instead.

choices.C: The IKE real time debug shows the phase 1 negotiation only. For information after that, the administrator must use the IPsec real time debug instead: diagnose debug application ipsec -1.
choices.A: The IKE real time shows the phases 1 and 2 negotiations only. It does not show any more output once the tunnel is up.
choices.B: The log-filter setting is set incorrectly. The VPN's traffic does not match this filter.
choices.D: The IKE real time debug shows error messages only. If it does not provide any output, it indicates that the tunnel is operating normally.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
A&C are correct

A - OK, D - wrong.
B - "newer been down" sounds like "now is up" and it is wrong.
But how about "never been down because never been up"? Unclear.
C - not finished TCP 3 way, can't be received anything. 
But OpenConfirm is a state, not a packet (a keep alive should be received).
Just guess what they meant...

Selected Answer: AC
only 2 prefixes have been received

"The last column is the neighbor state and number of prefixes. If the state is not established, this column displays the BGP state. If the state is established, this column displays the number of prefixes received by the local FortiGate from that neighbor."
A & C - 'Active' means the BGP Peer has not established a TCP Connection.

choices.D: The local BGP peer has received a total of 3 BGP prefixes.
choices.B: BGP peer 10.200.3.1 has never been down since the BGP counters were cleared.
choices.A: BGP state of the peer 10.125.0.60 is Established.
choices.C: Local BGP peer has not received an OpenConfirm from 10.200.3.1.

discussion.content:
The Fortinet device may not display all packets if too much information is requested to be displayed, or the traffic being sniffed is significant. When this occurs, the unit will log the following message once the trace is terminated:

12151 packets received by filter

3264 packets dropped by kernel

When this occurs, it is possible that what you were attempting to capture was not actually captured. In order to avoid this, you may try to tighten the display filters, reduce the verbose level, or perform the trace during a lower traffic period.
D - Captured by the configured Filter however unable to be displayed.

choices.A: Number of packets that didn't match the sniffer filter.
choices.B: Number of total packets dropped by the FortiGate.
choices.C: Number of packets that matched the sniffer filter and were dropped by the FortiGate.
choices.D: Number of packets that matched the sniffer filter but could not be captured by the sniffer.

choices.C: That DNS traffic from client workstations is allowed by the explicit web proxy policies.
choices.B: The connectivity between the client workstations and the DNS server.
choices.D: That DNS service is enabled in the explicit web proxy interface.
choices.A: The connectivity between the FortiGate unit and the DNS server.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Answer is A

Selected Answer: A
This is not a multiple answer question. Only A applies in Explicit Proxy Mode.
only A, in explicit proxy mode it is the FortiGate that resolves names not the client
A & B are the first two checks.
